BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 12, 1921

VARSITY -ALUMNI LA- FENNIMAN ELECTED EDITOR OF BLACK AND
CROSSE GAME ENDS
A TIE AT DUSK
BLUE JAY.
Each Team Shoots Six Goals—Three
Extra Periods Prove Useless,
•
Neither Squad Being Able
to Tally—Griffiss and
Bauerschmidt Star
for Regulars.

After playing through two regular periods and three extra fiveminute periods, the annual Varsity-Alumni game ended in a 6-to-6
tie on Saturday. It was 6.30 and
almost dusk when the final whistle
blew, and Captains Stuart and
Griffiss decided to call it a day
after two hours of hard playing.
The playing of the Varsity exceeded the fondest hopes of the
coaches, their passing, dodging
• and general play against their experienced opponents being excellent for a green team playing
their first game of the season.
The Alumni started off with a
• rush, and the Varsity goal was in
danger from the very first. The
defense played steady, however,
and stopped several strong advances until Baxley shot one past
Benedict, the ball being sent down
the field by beautiful passes from
Schmeisser to Wolfe to Baxley,
and the play then started up in
earnest, LaMotte getting the ball
on the crease and making a pretty
corner shot. Griffiss scored first
for the Varsity by dodging
Schmidt and working the ball in
• past Stuart for a goal. The play
was centered around the Alumni's
goal by this time, and it was only
through the wonderful work • of
Eddie Stuart at goal that the Varsity did not score much more frequently. The Varsity was just
getting started, while the Alumni,
through lack of training, were
pretty well fagged when the half
ended with the score 2 to 1 in their
favor.
The second half started off with
a goal from midfield by Chas.
Wolfe, who played a very fast
game at center. The -play was so
thick around him that he had to
quit immediately after this as the
• result of someone's stock landing
on him, breaking his nose.
"Dutch" Kauffman replaced him
at center. The Varsity then settled down to work, and two goals
by Griffiss and one by Bauernschmidt placed them in the lead.
Bauernschmidt's shot was a beautiful .1)iece of stick work. He re• ceived the ball from behind the
goal, and after dodging past the
Alumni's inner defense shot a
pretty goal. The Alumni scored
next, but Bauernschmidt came
back with a shot from the crease,
putting the Varsity in the lead
again. Baxley then made a free
shot, and Johnny Knipp put the
Alumni head, making the prettiest

Cotton To Be Business Manager—Next
Issue To Appear April 20—Last
Number Of Year To Be
Grads' Number.

On the resignations of the
Senior members of the Black and
Blue Jay staff Lawrence B. Fenneman, '23, was elected editor-inchief H. Douglas Cotton, '22,
business manager Joseph A. Moran, '23, managing editor, and
Quentin Singewald, '23, circulation manager. Paul S. Ives, '23,
and George Hardy, '23, have been
appointed assistant managing editor and art editor, respectively.
As result of the early spring
competition Benjamin S. Rich,
'23, made the editorial staff A. L.
Barson, '24, and Albert Duhman,
'24, the art staff, and 0. D. Collins,
'23, the business staff.
The Wine, Women and Song
Number, which will contain 28
pages, replete with foamy articles,
breezy jokes and snappy cartoons,
will appear about April 20.
Plans are now being made for
the Grads' Number, the last edition of the year to be distributed
on May 25. It is hoped that this
issue will be the best of the year,
crowning, as it were, the success
of the initial year of the magazine.
In order to do this the entire
student-body is requested by the
Board to give the Seniors a great
send-off.
Several positions on the staff
are still available and competition for the next issue is now
opened. A meeting of candidates
for the editorial and art staffs
will be held in Room 113 Wednesday, April 13.
FIVE NEW MEN ADMITTED TO
SIGMA CHI BETA

The first initiates of the Sigma
Chi Beta Honorary Fraternity
were presented with their pins at
a dance given by the society at the
Woman's Club, Roland Park, last
Saturday night. Ralph F. Bowers
presided, and Bartow Griffiss
made the presentation. The new
members of the organization are:
Elmer Jones, '21; Frederick R.
Calkins, Jr., '21; Johns U. Markel], '22; Richard N. Wood, '22,
and Forgraves,'23.
The dance, which was the first
given by the fraternity, proved a
great success in every way. Dancing started at 9 o'clock and continued until midnight. Johnson's
Orchestra supplied the music,
which was greatly improved when
"Mike" Bowers took his turn at
the piano. Light refreshments
were served during the intermissions. The arrangements were in
the hands of a committee composed of H.P. Brawner,0. S. Wilkinson and J. J. Dubbleall.

NONATHLETIC FEE APPORTIONED BY COMMITTEE
At a recent meeting of the Faculty Committee and a committee
from the Varsity Seal Voting
Council, the nonathletic fee for
the year 1921-1922 was awarded
as follows: Hullabaloo, $2.90;
NEWS-LETTER, $2; Daily Bulletin,
73 cents; Black and Blue Jay,
$1, Dramatic Club,$1.65 Musical
Club, 50 cents; Debating, 20 cents,
and Y. M. C. A., $1. It was found
extremely difficult to apportion
the sum, and concessions had to be
made all along the line. The
steadily increasing cost of printing was the chief obstable.
The question of the management
and distribution of the fund was
discussed at length, but no definite
decision was reached. It is probable, however, that the money will
be deposited in a lump sum subject to check, and the following
scheme of distribution be used:
All checks must be signed by some
one person, to be selected later,
who will keep the books for all activities and will represent the
Faculty Committee. The checks
will, in addition, be countersigned
by the business manager or some
one designated officer of the activity by whom it is drawn. No bills
will be. paid without adequate
vouchers, and the books will be
open to inspection at all times.
Any additioiltal money procured by •
an activity will be deposited to the
credit of that activity in the general fund, and any surplus at the
end of the year will be carried
over to the credit of the organization in the following year. The
expenses of the bookkeeper, vouchers and a surplus to meet probable
deficits will in all likelihood be
provided by taking 10 per cent.
of the total sum collected and placing it to the credit of the Varsity
Seal Voting Council, subject to
some restrictions, with the authority to make such payments.
Another meeting will be held in
the near future, and this question
will then be definitely decided.

PRICE 10 CENTS
HOPKINS SHUT OUT BY
DELAWARE COLLEGE
BASEBALLERS
Failure to Hit at Opportune Times
Loses Game for J. H. U.—Tucker
Pitches Well, But Weakens in
Third—Bill Wood Shines

Inability to hit in the pinches,
slow fielding and the bunching of
four hits off of Tucker in the third
inning of Saturday's game at
Homewood cost the Hopkins balltossers the fourth game of the season, Delaware College being the
victors by a 2-to-0 score. In three
innings the local team managed to
fill the bases, only to have the succeeding batters fail miserably in
their attempts at run producing.
Again, in the ninth inning, with
Wood and Chandler, who batted
for Tucker, on the bases and only
one out, at a time when a hit
would surely have meant tieing
the score, Strouse and Grace were
unable to connect safely.
Tucker, the Hopkins twirler,
hurled an excellent game, striking
out five men and having matters
pretty much in his own hands except in the unlucky third stanza.
Rothrock, although touched for
but three hits, failed to pitch in
the form which he displayed
against Hopkins in the first Delaware contest on Easter Monday.
Bill Wood proved himself the star
for the locals, gathering in two of
the three hits made by them, in
addition to giving a wonderful exhibition of throwing to second and
third, by which he cut down opponent base-runners time after
time. Marvel, the Delaware receiver, also distinguished himself
by his timely hitting.
Wilson opened the third inning,
which caused Hopkins' downfall,
by making Delaware's second hit
of the contest, a ball which Rich,
in left field, misjudged and let go
over his head. Donoho sacrificed,

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 12, 1921

2
CANE CLUB HAS FIRST TAP
DAY.
Members Drive Into Homewood In
Coaches And Victorias—New Men
Received In Front Of Gilman Hall.
There were many who believed
that the old-fashioned horse-drawn
hack had gone out of existence in
this section of the country. So
unaccustomed are the members of
this generation to these time-honored vehicles which have been replaced by the swifter automobile
that they stop and stare whenever
a cab with its driver in a high silk
hat or a victoria, with livery
coachman passes. But they were
not the only ones to stare when,
on Wednesday before Easter, a
procession of four came driving
through the university grounds at
a quiet gate. The equipment
showed signs of a recent polishing
up. In the carriages were members of the Cane Club proceeding
to their tapping exercises on the
quadrangle, each with a large,
white carnation in his lapel, his
cane and not too austere a face.
"Tubby" Turner drove the last
cab himself, perched on the driver's seat in true style, with a high
silk hat resting jauntily on top of.
him.
The candidates for admission to
the Cane Club were lined up in
formation in front of Gilman Hall
when the procession arrived.
Elmer Jones, armed with his cane,
then spoke to each one, inviting
him to join the Cane Club, and
Bartow Griffiss, who followed, presented each with a white carnation. There was then a grouping
made for a picture and all piled
back into the cabs, the new men
in the rear coach, driven by Coachman Turner. As the teams passed
off the quadrangle there was a general expression of sentiment
among the undergraduate onlook-

R. 0. T. C. PREPARING FOR
INSPECTION.
Lieutenant Williams Promoted To Captaincy—Dance To Be Given By
Unit On April 29.

The R. 0. T. C. this week started
its period of intensive drill which
will continue until the big inspection, which will take place toward
the close of May. Every member
of the unit is working hard to
place the university way up on the
list of "distinguished" institutions
and there is no reason why this
cannot be achieved.
Lieutenant Williams, who is the
most recent addition to the corps
of officers at the university, has
been raised to the rank of captain.
Lieutenant-Colonel Lee will join
the military department for a
months' instruction in the near
future, as will also Colonel Lind3fty, who was a brigadier-general
during the war. A large number
of officers who intend becoming
professors of military science and
tactics at other colleges next year
are being assigned to Hopkins to
study our methods and "learn the
ropes."
The R. 0. T. C. is planning to
give an informal dance on April
29. The price of admission will
be $2 a couple and men outside
the unit will be welcome. The
uniform will not be worn at the
dance. An effort is being made to
obtain Iula's orchestra, but
whether this is successful or not
good music and plenty of it is
promised to all. Dean and Mrs.
Whitehead have promised to be
among the patrons.

MT. ST. JOSEPHS DEFEATS
FRESHMEN.
Five Runs In First Inning Sufficient
To Subdue First-Year Ball Tossers.
Ellicott Pitches Well.

In the first ,game of the season
the Freshmen Baseball Team was
defeated by Mount St. Josephs, 6
to 3, in seven innings. The first
inning proved disastrous to Hopkins, very loose playing by the
infield giving the Josephites five
runs, four of which were unearned.
After this the team settled down
and Ellicott, who pitched a splendid game throughout, had the
game in his own hands. Mount
St. Josephs only made two scattered hits in the other six innings,
their other run coming from a
passed ball. The Freshmen got
to Brehm in the sixth and knocked
in three runs after two were out.
Hutzler, who took Morovitz's
place at first, knocked in two of
these runs with a long hit to left
field, which only netted him two
bases, as he slipped rounding first
base. Strouse and Donetell played
well for the Freshmen, the former
making a one-hand stab at a line
drive in the seventh which prevented a run, and the latter making two clean hits in four times
up. Brehm pitched a steady game
for Mount St. Joseph. With more
constant practice and a better
balanced line-up the Freshmen
should put out a team which will
be up to the standard of their
other teams and give trouble to
local prep schools. The boxscore:

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LE FTER, APRIL 12, 1921

NAPOLEON SUBJECT OF W.& L. AND N. C. DEBATERS
ADDRESS AT ASSEMBLY.
TO MEET AT HOPKINS.

BALL

Dr. Rose, Of Cambridge, Eminent Authority On French Emperor—Gives
Outline Of His Life—Talk
Accompanied By Lantern
Slides.

Virginia Succumbs In Initial Contest
of Season—Hopkins Ties Delaware In Final Stanza—Dartmouth Wins By NinthInning Rally.

Prof. J. Holland Rose, of Cambridge University, introduced by
Dean Latane as "the most eminent
authority we have on Napoleon,"
addressed the assembly on Thursday of last week on the subject
"The Life of Napoleon I."
Professor Rose has written a
book of two volumes on this same
topic. He is professor of naval
history at Cambridge.
Professor Rose modestly disclaimed any idea of his deserving
the terms in which the dean spoke
of him. He then said that he could
deal with his subject in a talk of
only one hour from the scenic
aspect alone, leaving untouched
the phases of policy, naval and
military tactics, and even the discussion of the results of Napoleon's influence on the world.
He said, too, that, as the centennial of the death of the great
leader, which occurred May 5,
1821, was approaching, his talk
would prepare us somewhat for it.
Then, with the help of his slides,
some of which were taken from
contemporaries' engravings, others
of which were maps, and still
others that were from famous
paintings of incidents in the life
of the "little Corsican," he
sketched his life through his
ascent into fame and his equally
speedy fall. Even though he did
come close to political lunacy by
ruling contrary to the comnion
sense ideas of the public of all
Europe, nevertheless the French
(Professor Rose said that when
he crowned himself emperor he
chose the title "Emperor, of the
French" rather than "King of
Prance" or "Emperor of France"),
his beloved French, still adored
him in his ruin as they had cheered
him in his successes.
After briefly outlining Elba,
the Hundred Days, Waterloo and
St. Helena, Professor Rose concluded his interesting, too brief
lecture with a quotation from the
poet Shelley.

Immigration To Be Subject Again On
April 30.—Hopkins Men To Go
South—Dance To Follow
Debate.

Plans for the annual Intercollegiate Triangular Debate of
Johns Hopkins, North Carolina
and Washington and Lee to be
held on April 30 at the three institutions are well under way. Hopkins will be represented on the
affirmative team by Dorsey Watkins,'22; Parker C. Williams,'23,
and Morris Keene, '21, alternate,
and on the negative by Adolphus
Emmart, '23; Albert Dimond,
'23, and B. S. Cannon, '21, alternate.
The varsity affirmative team
will meet Washington and Lee at
North Carolina and the negative,
North Carolina at Washington
and Lee. The subject is: "Resolved,
That the United States should
adopt a policy of further material
restriction of immigration."
The Washington and Lee affirmative and the North Carolina
negative teams will hold their
verbal battle in the assembly hall
of the Civil Engineering Building
at 8 P. M. April 30. Music will
be furnished by Mike Bowers' orchestra. A dance and other features are being arranged by Bartus Trew, manager of the debate.

BISHOP

NICOLAI SPEAKS
SERBIA.

ON

The first weekly assembly after
the return of the student-body
from the Easter vacation, on
March 31, was addressed by
Bishop - Nicolai of the Orthodox
Serbian Church on the subject of
conditions in Serbia and the remainder of Europe. Bishop Nicolai, who was introduced by
President Goodnow, astounded his
audience with the stories of the
massacres of his countrymen by
the Turks, who always either
killed or converted their captives
who were of any religious sect
other then theirs. He also stated
that the Serbian losses in the war
were 1,300,000 lives out of a population of 4,000,000, representing a
loss greater then the combined
losses of England and America.
In conclusion Bishop Nicolai
urged everyone to help, not merely
materially, but spiritually, stricken Europe to recover her position
as the bulwark of civilization.

TEAM WINS, TIES
AND• LOSES.

Since the last number of the
NEWS-LETTER appeared the Hopkins baseball team has got well
into its season stride. Within
the last two weeks the team has
played four of its games, winning
one, tying one and losing one (the
result of last Saturday's game is
still in doubt as we go to press),
but in every case showing a quality of playing that has not been
present in Black and Blue nines
for several years. This quality
first became manifest when the
team journeyed to Charlottesville
on March 26 and beat the University of Virginia by the score of
11 to 5. The result of the Virginia setto came as a decided surprise to most people, especially
as Hopkins this spring has a team
composed largely of new and hitherto untried men.
The game with Delaware on
March 28 resulted in a tie. Both
teams had made five runs at the
end of the ninth inning when it
became too dark for further playing.
The game scheduled with the
University of Pennsylvania for
March 31 was called on account
of rain.
On Saturday, April 2, Dartmouth defeated Hopkins at Homewood by getting three runs in the
*ninth, making the final score 6
to 3.
In the game with Virginia
Tucker pitched until the sixth
inning, when Marchetti took the
box until the finish.
The Virginians started off well, bagging
two runs in the first inning,
while Hopkins did not score till
the third, when Grace crossed
the plate for their initial run of
the season. Sexton, of Virginia,
brought his team's score up to
three runs in the third, at which
tally it remained until the seventh.
It was the fifth that was the lucky
inning for J. H. U. Hayter,
Sharrets, Wood, Knecht and Reifschneider crossed the plate one
after the other. Bill Wood scored
again in the sixth, and in the
seventh and eighth four more runs
brought the score to 11 to 5.
In the Johns Hopkins-Delaware
game both teams were working
under great difficulties. The hot
weather that had prevailed up to
then changed at the beginning of
the game to freezing with a wind
storm that throughout the game
made the ball exceedingly difficult toe ontrol. Owings pitched in
wonderful form, striking out six
men and walking only one. Tucker,
pitching in the ninth, struck out
two of the three batters that came
up before him. Rich scored Hopkins' first run in the third inning.
Reifschneider, Rich and Owings
scored in the seventh. The score
now remained 5 to 4 in favor of

DRAMATIC CLUB FORCED
TO LAY ASIDE PLANS
FOR TRIP.
Impossible To Obtain Backing For PerFormances Out Of Town—"Play
Night" To Be Given In May.
Actors Turning Authors.

For several weeks the Dramatic
Club has been entertaining hopes
of taking "Arms and the Man"
on the road and making a short
tour of the towns in Western
Maryland. During the holidays
the officers of the club made a visit
to some of the more prominent organizations in Frederick and
Hagerstown in an effort to get one
of them to underwrite the club for
its expenses by given a benefit and
guaranteeing a minimum sum.
Correspondence has been exchanged, with the result that they
do not feel able to do so at this
time. The club will devote its activities for the rest of the year to
small plays in the studio and will
give another,"Play Night" in May.
There are several playlets on hand
written by several members of the
cast to "Arms •and the Man,"
which will be rearranged and
staged in the Barn. Any others
which are contributed will be
given due consideration and will
be put on as soon as a cast can be
gotten together and rehearsed.
the visitors until the ninth, when
Rothrock, Delaware's pitcher,
walked Hayter, who reached second on a passed ball, and was
brought home by Sharrett's single. With the score tied the game
was called by Umpire Brockman
on account of darkness.
Dartmouth on April 2 was held
to a tie until the ninth inning,
when a home run by Robertson, of
Dartmouth, and runs by Lynch
and Tracey clinched the game for
the visiting team. The game
ended, 6 to 3.

"Do you think we are happier
for the conveniences of telegraph
and telephone?"
"Not always," replied Senator
Sorghum. "It would be a great
comfort to be able to make a
speech that exactly agrees with
your audience without its being
placed immediately before people
all over the country who may not
feel the same way about it"—

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 12, 1921

THE SPRING SEASON
TICKET
We are publishing on page 2 the
spring athletic schedule, and hope
in this way to call attention to.the
advantages of the season ticket.
Not only does it provide the purchaser with an unusual number of
attractions at a minimum cost, but
at the same time it provides the
University an additional supporter.
Last year an intensive selling
campaign was carried on and a
great many tickets sold. The students are asked to co-operate
again this year by bringing the
proposition to the attention of
their friends and any other people
whom they feel might be interested. The tickets may be obtained by writing to or appearing
in person at the athletic office.
ABRAHAM FEDDER'S
LETTER
We publish in our letter column
of this issue an exceedingly eloquent appeal in behalf of the poor
student. This appeal is well
worth reading, although there
seems to be little basis for the
writer's complaints. The chief
purpose of the letter, so far as we
can gather, is to urge exemption
from payment of the nonathletic
fee for those who really cannot afford to pay it. Since the "well-to:
do students" who, according to the

writer, thrust this tax upon a misguided student body, at the very
beginning provided for the exemption of such students by the Dean,
the main point of the letter is at
once taken away.
The text of the letter, howevor,
is well worth our perusal. The
writer apparently believes that
the nonathletic fee is the "result
of a vote taken in an illogical moblike fashion." We disagree with
him. The proposition was printed
and discussed fully some time in
advance (as eprly as last May the
NEWS-LETTER made the suggestion,
but it was unfortunately too late
to put it into operation, so it was
never submitted to a vote by the
student body). It was presented
in an exceedingly able and logical
manner at a student assembly, received the endorsement of various
leaders in the Atudent body, including that of,the writer of this.
letter, and was then passed unanimously by the students.
The writer also stated that "in
initation of our wise national
leaders the well-to-do students are
imposing the share of the expense
of their peculiar (the italics are
ours) desires upon those who cannot bear them." We do not believe
that those chiefly influential in
passing the nonathletic fee can be
honestly termed well-to-do, and
since the Dean can excuse those
not in a position to pay the fee, it
cannot be said that it is imposed
upon those who cannot bear it.
The fee was inaugurated primarily to give the activities the
necessary funds at the beginning
of the year instead of at the end.
It was aimed at the procrastinating student who, while perfectly
willing and able to pay, always
puts off doing so until the last
minute. If at the same time it
gets some of the slackers who, although in a position to do so, refuse to support any college activity, so much the better. We are
heartily glad of it, and feel that
the student body as a whole shares
our delight and is equally desirous
of seeing this type of student eliminated from the University rolls.
In calling the nonathletic fee a
"nonessential tax" and nonathletic
activities "the peculiar desire" of
these men, we believe that the
writer displays a misguided opinion. The fee is necessary if these
activities are to be placed on a
par with similar activities in other
educational institutions. It is also
necessary in order that the burden of their support fall equally
upon all who are able to bear it.
If the desire to have our University rank with other leading colleges in undergraduate life is peculiar, the writer is perfectly justified.
The writer also complains
against the payment of the NEWSLETTER and other "noncontracted"
debts from the balance of the students' caution money. We do not
believe that any "noncontracted"
debts are collected in such a manner. If the writer were acquainted with the law, he would know

that anyone who receives any publication and does not notify the
Postoffice authorities that he desires its discontinuance, is legally
bound to pay for it. The NEWSLETTER and other publications are
placed in the student's box in the
expectation that he .will pay for
it as soon as possible, and if he
does not wish it, the time to say
so is at the beginning of the year,
and not at the end, when he has
received the use of it throughout
that time. Class dues are also
justly contracted debts, and the
way to avoid their payment is by
excuse from the treasurer, and not
by ducking at the last minute. Of
course, we realize that some students do not realize that the class,
much less class dues, exist, and
therefore such knowledge comes
as a severe shock. If any other
payments are collected from the
caution money, we feel perfectly
sure that they are justly contiacted, and therefore are indisputable.
We regret the writer's attitude in
this matter, and feel sure that it
does not represent fairly the average poor student. In fact, we
heard some of these men express
the opinion that after they have
succeeded in getting through the
year and met their expenses, they
are only too glad to do their bit to
support the activities by payment
of their NEWS-LETTER and other
bills from their caution money.
We have the greatest sympathy
for the "poor searcher for wisdom," and have no desire to see
this element eliminated from the
student body. We have proved
that the nonathletic fee is not
aimed at this class of students
which Fedders so eloquently describes. We have, however, not
the slightest feeling of charity for
those parasites upon our Alma
Mater who take all from her without giving her the slightest thing
in return, and if the nonathletic
fee will in any way eliminate or
embarrass such students, we are
heartily thankful.

THE WRITER OF THIS LETTER IS
EVIDENTLY NOT IN PERFECT ACCORD WITH THE DEAN.
To the Editor of the News-Letter:

Sir—Your editorial in. the issue
of March 22 professes a mournful
surprise at the rapid and unwept
decease of the "weakly" assembly.
May I be so boorish as to rise
and ask, What has been the specific purpose of these meetings?
Has it been instruction or entertainment? Doubtless my sense of
values is woefully depraved, but I

confess- I have been unable to extract any edification, advantage or
pleasure from most of these gatherings. Nor is this condition to
be marveled at, when the program
is constituted somewhat as follow*: First, the dean mounts the
platform and "obliges" with a linguistic ramble wherein he takes to
task and direly threatens certain
wrongdoers (who, by the way, are
never present to benefit by these
half per cent. philippics); then
some brief routine announcement

In the second annual interclass
track meet, held last Friday afternoon at Homewood, the class of
1923 was again victorious, capturing 97 points, more than three
times as many as their nearest
opponents. The Seniors finished
second, with 32 points, while the
Freshmen and Juniors brought up
the rear with 24 and 12 points,
respectively.
In the individual scoring Aaronson lead the field with three firsts
and a second. It was especially
gratifying to see the excellent
showing made by men who had
not been out for track before.
This was, of course, partly due to
the fact that handicaps were given
in the meet this year, but, nevertheless, much new material was
uncovered. Clark, a Sophomore,
showed good form in the dashes,
winning both the 100 and 220
yard events. In the quarter-mile
Edwards ran a beautiful race.
Starting from scratch he overtook
a large field and won by a wide
margin.

After playing through two regular periods and three extra fiveminute periods, the annual Varsity-Alumni game ended in a 6-to-6
tie on Saturday. It was 6.30 and
almost dusk when the final whistle
blew, and Captains Stuart and
Griffiss decided to call it a day
after two hours of hard playing.
The playing of the Varsity exceeded the fondest hopes of the
coaches, their passing, dodging
• and general play against their experienced opponents being excellent for a green team playing
their first game of the season.
The Alumni started off with a
• rush, and the Varsity goal was in
danger from the very first. The
defense played steady, however,
and stopped several strong advances until Baxley shot one past
Benedict, the ball being sent down
the field by beautiful passes from
Schmeisser to Wolfe to Baxley,
and the play then started up in
earnest, LaMotte getting the ball
on the crease and making a pretty
corner shot. Griffiss scored first
for the Varsity by dodging
Schmidt and working the ball in
• past Stuart for a goal. The play
was centered around the Alumni's
goal by this time, and it was only
through the wonderful work • of
Eddie Stuart at goal that the Varsity did not score much more frequently. The Varsity was just
getting started, while the Alumni,
through lack of training, were
pretty well fagged when the half
ended with the score 2 to 1 in their
favor.
The second half started off with
a goal from midfield by Chas.
Wolfe, who played a very fast
game at center. The -play was so
thick around him that he had to
quit immediately after this as the
• result of someone's stock landing
on him, breaking his nose.
"Dutch" Kauffman replaced him
at center. The Varsity then settled down to work, and two goals
by Griffiss and one by Bauernschmidt placed them in the lead.

goal, and after dodging past the

pretty goal. The Alumni scored
next, but Bauernschmidt came
back with a shot from the crease,
putting the Varsity in the lead
again. Baxley then made a free
shot, and Johnny Knipp put the

Cotton To Be Business Manager—Next
Issue To Appear April 20—Last
Number Of Year To Be
Grads' Number.

On the resignations of the
Senior members of the Black and
Blue Jay staff Lawrence B. Fenneman, '23, was elected editor-inchief H. Douglas Cotton, '22,
business manager Joseph A. Moran, '23, managing editor, and
Quentin Singewald, '23, circulation manager. Paul S. Ives, '23,
and George Hardy, '23, have been
appointed assistant managing editor and art editor, respectively.
As result of the early spring
competition Benjamin S. Rich,
'23, made the editorial staff A. L.
Barson, '24, and Albert Duhman,
'24, the art staff, and 0. D. Collins,
'23, the business staff.
The Wine, Women and Song
Number, which will contain 28
pages, replete with foamy articles,
breezy jokes and snappy cartoons,
will appear about April 20.
Plans are now being made for
the Grads' Number, the last edition of the year to be distributed
on May 25. It is hoped that this
issue will be the best of the year,
crowning, as it were, the success
of the initial year of the magazine.
In order to do this the entire
student-body is requested by the
Board to give the Seniors a great
send-off.
Several positions on the staff
are still available and competition for the next issue is now
opened. A meeting of candidates
for the editorial and art staffs
will be held in Room 113 Wednesday, April 13.
FIVE NEW MEN ADMITTED TO
SIGMA CHI BETA

The first initiates of the Sigma
Chi Beta Honorary Fraternity
were presented with their pins at
a dance given by the society at the
Woman's Club, Roland Park, last
Saturday night. Ralph F. Bowers
presided, and Bartow Griffiss
made the presentation. The new
members of the organization are:
Elmer Jones, '21; Frederick R.
Calkins, Jr., '21; Johns U. Markel], '22; Richard N. Wood, '22,
and Forgraves,'23.
The dance, which was the first
given by the fraternity, proved a
great success in every way. Dancing started at 9 o'clock and continued until midnight. Johnson's
Orchestra supplied the music,
which was greatly improved when
"Mike" Bowers took his turn at
the piano. Light refreshments
were served during the intermissions. The arrangements were in
the hands of a committee composed of H.P. Brawner,0. S. Wilkinson and J. J. Dubbleall.

NONATHLETIC FEE APPORTIONED BY COMMITTEE
At a recent meeting of the Faculty Committee and a committee
from the Varsity Seal Voting
Council, the nonathletic fee for
the year 1921-1922 was awarded
as follows: Hullabaloo, $2.90;
NEWS-LETTER, $2; Daily Bulletin,
73 cents; Black and Blue Jay,
$1, Dramatic Club,$1.65 Musical
Club, 50 cents; Debating, 20 cents,
and Y. M. C. A., $1. It was found
extremely difficult to apportion
the sum, and concessions had to be
made all along the line. The
steadily increasing cost of printing was the chief obstable.
The question of the management
and distribution of the fund was
discussed at length, but no definite
decision was reached. It is probable, however, that the money will
be deposited in a lump sum subject to check, and the following
scheme of distribution be used:
All checks must be signed by some
one person, to be selected later,
who will keep the books for all activities and will represent the
Faculty Committee. The checks
will, in addition, be countersigned
by the business manager or some
one designated officer of the activity by whom it is drawn. No bills
will be. paid without adequate
vouchers, and the books will be
open to inspection at all times.
Any additioiltal money procured by •
an activity will be deposited to the
credit of that activity in the general fund, and any surplus at the
end of the year will be carried
over to the credit of the organization in the following year. The
expenses of the bookkeeper, vouchers and a surplus to meet probable
deficits will in all likelihood be
provided by taking 10 per cent.
of the total sum collected and placing it to the credit of the Varsity
Seal Voting Council, subject to
some restrictions, with the authority to make such payments.
Another meeting will be held in
the near future, and this question
will then be definitely decided.

innings the local team managed to
fill the bases, only to have the succeeding batters fail miserably in

for Tucker, on the bases and only
one out, at a time when a hit
would surely have meant tieing
the score, Strouse and Grace were
unable to connect safely.
Tucker, the Hopkins twirler,
hurled an excellent game, striking
out five men and having matters
pretty much in his own hands except in the unlucky third stanza.
Rothrock, although touched for
but three hits, failed to pitch in
the form which he displayed
against Hopkins in the first Delaware contest on Easter Monday.

addition to giving a wonderful exhibition of throwing to second and
third, by which he cut down opponent base-runners time after
time. Marvel, the Delaware receiver, also distinguished himself
by his timely hitting.
Wilson opened the third inning,
which caused Hopkins' downfall,

CANE CLUB HAS FIRST TAP
DAY.
Members Drive Into Homewood In
Coaches And Victorias—New Men
Received In Front Of Gilman Hall.
There were many who believed
that the old-fashioned horse-drawn
hack had gone out of existence in
this section of the country. So
unaccustomed are the members of
this generation to these time-honored vehicles which have been replaced by the swifter automobile
that they stop and stare whenever
a cab with its driver in a high silk
hat or a victoria, with livery
coachman passes. But they were
not the only ones to stare when,
on Wednesday before Easter, a
procession of four came driving
through the university grounds at
a quiet gate. The equipment
showed signs of a recent polishing
up. In the carriages were members of the Cane Club proceeding
to their tapping exercises on the
quadrangle, each with a large,
white carnation in his lapel, his
cane and not too austere a face.
"Tubby" Turner drove the last
cab himself, perched on the driver's seat in true style, with a high
silk hat resting jauntily on top of.
him.
The candidates for admission to
the Cane Club were lined up in
formation in front of Gilman Hall
when the procession arrived.
Elmer Jones, armed with his cane,
then spoke to each one, inviting
him to join the Cane Club, and
Bartow Griffiss, who followed, presented each with a white carnation. There was then a grouping
made for a picture and all piled
back into the cabs, the new men
in the rear coach, driven by Coachman Turner. As the teams passed
off the quadrangle there was a general expression of sentiment
among the undergraduate onlook-

R. 0. T. C. PREPARING FOR
INSPECTION.
Lieutenant Williams Promoted To Captaincy—Dance To Be Given By
Unit On April 29.

The R. 0. T. C. this week started
its period of intensive drill which
will continue until the big inspection, which will take place toward
the close of May. Every member
of the unit is working hard to
place the university way up on the
list of "distinguished" institutions
and there is no reason why this
cannot be achieved.
Lieutenant Williams, who is the
most recent addition to the corps
of officers at the university, has
been raised to the rank of captain.
Lieutenant-Colonel Lee will join
the military department for a
months' instruction in the near
future, as will also Colonel Lind3fty, who was a brigadier-general
during the war. A large number
of officers who intend becoming
professors of military science and
tactics at other colleges next year
are being assigned to Hopkins to
study our methods and "learn the
ropes."
The R. 0. T. C. is planning to
give an informal dance on April
29. The price of admission will
be $2 a couple and men outside
the unit will be welcome. The
uniform will not be worn at the
dance. An effort is being made to
obtain Iula's orchestra, but
whether this is successful or not
good music and plenty of it is
promised to all. Dean and Mrs.
Whitehead have promised to be
among the patrons.

MT. ST. JOSEPHS DEFEATS
FRESHMEN.
Five Runs In First Inning Sufficient
To Subdue First-Year Ball Tossers.
Ellicott Pitches Well.

In the first ,game of the season
the Freshmen Baseball Team was
defeated by Mount St. Josephs, 6
to 3, in seven innings. The first
inning proved disastrous to Hopkins, very loose playing by the
infield giving the Josephites five
runs, four of which were unearned.
After this the team settled down
and Ellicott, who pitched a splendid game throughout, had the
game in his own hands. Mount
St. Josephs only made two scattered hits in the other six innings,
their other run coming from a
passed ball. The Freshmen got
to Brehm in the sixth and knocked
in three runs after two were out.
Hutzler, who took Morovitz's
place at first, knocked in two of
these runs with a long hit to left
field, which only netted him two
bases, as he slipped rounding first
base. Strouse and Donetell played
well for the Freshmen, the former
making a one-hand stab at a line
drive in the seventh which prevented a run, and the latter making two clean hits in four times
up. Brehm pitched a steady game
for Mount St. Joseph. With more
constant practice and a better
balanced line-up the Freshmen
should put out a team which will
be up to the standard of their
other teams and give trouble to
local prep schools. The boxscore:

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LE FTER, APRIL 12, 1921

NAPOLEON SUBJECT OF W.& L. AND N. C. DEBATERS
ADDRESS AT ASSEMBLY.
TO MEET AT HOPKINS.

BALL

Dr. Rose, Of Cambridge, Eminent Authority On French Emperor—Gives
Outline Of His Life—Talk
Accompanied By Lantern
Slides.

Virginia Succumbs In Initial Contest
of Season—Hopkins Ties Delaware In Final Stanza—Dartmouth Wins By NinthInning Rally.

Prof. J. Holland Rose, of Cambridge University, introduced by
Dean Latane as "the most eminent
authority we have on Napoleon,"
addressed the assembly on Thursday of last week on the subject
"The Life of Napoleon I."
Professor Rose has written a
book of two volumes on this same
topic. He is professor of naval
history at Cambridge.
Professor Rose modestly disclaimed any idea of his deserving
the terms in which the dean spoke
of him. He then said that he could
deal with his subject in a talk of
only one hour from the scenic
aspect alone, leaving untouched
the phases of policy, naval and
military tactics, and even the discussion of the results of Napoleon's influence on the world.
He said, too, that, as the centennial of the death of the great
leader, which occurred May 5,
1821, was approaching, his talk
would prepare us somewhat for it.
Then, with the help of his slides,
some of which were taken from
contemporaries' engravings, others
of which were maps, and still
others that were from famous
paintings of incidents in the life
of the "little Corsican," he
sketched his life through his
ascent into fame and his equally
speedy fall. Even though he did
come close to political lunacy by
ruling contrary to the comnion
sense ideas of the public of all
Europe, nevertheless the French
(Professor Rose said that when
he crowned himself emperor he
chose the title "Emperor, of the
French" rather than "King of
Prance" or "Emperor of France"),
his beloved French, still adored
him in his ruin as they had cheered
him in his successes.
After briefly outlining Elba,
the Hundred Days, Waterloo and
St. Helena, Professor Rose concluded his interesting, too brief
lecture with a quotation from the
poet Shelley.

Immigration To Be Subject Again On
April 30.—Hopkins Men To Go
South—Dance To Follow
Debate.

Plans for the annual Intercollegiate Triangular Debate of
Johns Hopkins, North Carolina
and Washington and Lee to be
held on April 30 at the three institutions are well under way. Hopkins will be represented on the
affirmative team by Dorsey Watkins,'22; Parker C. Williams,'23,
and Morris Keene, '21, alternate,
and on the negative by Adolphus
Emmart, '23; Albert Dimond,
'23, and B. S. Cannon, '21, alternate.
The varsity affirmative team
will meet Washington and Lee at
North Carolina and the negative,
North Carolina at Washington
and Lee. The subject is: "Resolved,
That the United States should
adopt a policy of further material
restriction of immigration."
The Washington and Lee affirmative and the North Carolina
negative teams will hold their
verbal battle in the assembly hall
of the Civil Engineering Building
at 8 P. M. April 30. Music will
be furnished by Mike Bowers' orchestra. A dance and other features are being arranged by Bartus Trew, manager of the debate.

BISHOP

NICOLAI SPEAKS
SERBIA.

ON

The first weekly assembly after
the return of the student-body
from the Easter vacation, on
March 31, was addressed by
Bishop - Nicolai of the Orthodox
Serbian Church on the subject of
conditions in Serbia and the remainder of Europe. Bishop Nicolai, who was introduced by
President Goodnow, astounded his
audience with the stories of the
massacres of his countrymen by
the Turks, who always either
killed or converted their captives
who were of any religious sect
other then theirs. He also stated
that the Serbian losses in the war
were 1,300,000 lives out of a population of 4,000,000, representing a
loss greater then the combined
losses of England and America.
In conclusion Bishop Nicolai
urged everyone to help, not merely
materially, but spiritually, stricken Europe to recover her position
as the bulwark of civilization.

TEAM WINS, TIES
AND• LOSES.

Since the last number of the
NEWS-LETTER appeared the Hopkins baseball team has got well
into its season stride. Within
the last two weeks the team has
played four of its games, winning
one, tying one and losing one (the
result of last Saturday's game is
still in doubt as we go to press),
but in every case showing a quality of playing that has not been
present in Black and Blue nines
for several years. This quality
first became manifest when the
team journeyed to Charlottesville
on March 26 and beat the University of Virginia by the score of
11 to 5. The result of the Virginia setto came as a decided surprise to most people, especially
as Hopkins this spring has a team
composed largely of new and hitherto untried men.
The game with Delaware on
March 28 resulted in a tie. Both
teams had made five runs at the
end of the ninth inning when it
became too dark for further playing.
The game scheduled with the
University of Pennsylvania for
March 31 was called on account
of rain.
On Saturday, April 2, Dartmouth defeated Hopkins at Homewood by getting three runs in the
*ninth, making the final score 6
to 3.
In the game with Virginia
Tucker pitched until the sixth
inning, when Marchetti took the
box until the finish.
The Virginians started off well, bagging
two runs in the first inning,
while Hopkins did not score till
the third, when Grace crossed
the plate for their initial run of
the season. Sexton, of Virginia,
brought his team's score up to
three runs in the third, at which
tally it remained until the seventh.
It was the fifth that was the lucky
inning for J. H. U. Hayter,
Sharrets, Wood, Knecht and Reifschneider crossed the plate one
after the other. Bill Wood scored
again in the sixth, and in the
seventh and eighth four more runs
brought the score to 11 to 5.
In the Johns Hopkins-Delaware
game both teams were working
under great difficulties. The hot
weather that had prevailed up to
then changed at the beginning of
the game to freezing with a wind
storm that throughout the game
made the ball exceedingly difficult toe ontrol. Owings pitched in
wonderful form, striking out six
men and walking only one. Tucker,
pitching in the ninth, struck out
two of the three batters that came
up before him. Rich scored Hopkins' first run in the third inning.
Reifschneider, Rich and Owings
scored in the seventh. The score
now remained 5 to 4 in favor of

Actors Turning Authors.

For several weeks the Dramatic
Club has been entertaining hopes
of taking "Arms and the Man"
on the road and making a short
tour of the towns in Western
Maryland. During the holidays
the officers of the club made a visit
to some of the more prominent organizations in Frederick and
Hagerstown in an effort to get one
of them to underwrite the club for
its expenses by given a benefit and
guaranteeing a minimum sum.
Correspondence has been exchanged, with the result that they
do not feel able to do so at this
time. The club will devote its activities for the rest of the year to
small plays in the studio and will
give another,"Play Night" in May.
There are several playlets on hand
written by several members of the
cast to "Arms •and the Man,"
which will be rearranged and
staged in the Barn. Any others
which are contributed will be
given due consideration and will
be put on as soon as a cast can be
gotten together and rehearsed.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 12, 1921

THE SPRING SEASON
TICKET
We are publishing on page 2 the
spring athletic schedule, and hope
in this way to call attention to.the
advantages of the season ticket.
Not only does it provide the purchaser with an unusual number of
attractions at a minimum cost, but
at the same time it provides the
University an additional supporter.
Last year an intensive selling
campaign was carried on and a
great many tickets sold. The students are asked to co-operate
again this year by bringing the
proposition to the attention of
their friends and any other people
whom they feel might be interested. The tickets may be obtained by writing to or appearing
in person at the athletic office.
ABRAHAM FEDDER'S
LETTER
We publish in our letter column
of this issue an exceedingly eloquent appeal in behalf of the poor
student. This appeal is well
worth reading, although there
seems to be little basis for the
writer's complaints. The chief
purpose of the letter, so far as we
can gather, is to urge exemption
from payment of the nonathletic
fee for those who really cannot afford to pay it. Since the "well-to:
do students" who, according to the

writer, thrust this tax upon a misguided student body, at the very
beginning provided for the exemption of such students by the Dean,
the main point of the letter is at
once taken away.
The text of the letter, howevor,
is well worth our perusal. The
writer apparently believes that
the nonathletic fee is the "result
of a vote taken in an illogical moblike fashion." We disagree with
him. The proposition was printed
and discussed fully some time in
advance (as eprly as last May the
NEWS-LETTER made the suggestion,
but it was unfortunately too late
to put it into operation, so it was
never submitted to a vote by the
student body). It was presented
in an exceedingly able and logical
manner at a student assembly, received the endorsement of various
leaders in the Atudent body, including that of,the writer of this.
letter, and was then passed unanimously by the students.
The writer also stated that "in
initation of our wise national
leaders the well-to-do students are
imposing the share of the expense
of their peculiar (the italics are
ours) desires upon those who cannot bear them." We do not believe
that those chiefly influential in
passing the nonathletic fee can be
honestly termed well-to-do, and
since the Dean can excuse those
not in a position to pay the fee, it
cannot be said that it is imposed
upon those who cannot bear it.
The fee was inaugurated primarily to give the activities the
necessary funds at the beginning
of the year instead of at the end.
It was aimed at the procrastinating student who, while perfectly
willing and able to pay, always
puts off doing so until the last
minute. If at the same time it
gets some of the slackers who, although in a position to do so, refuse to support any college activity, so much the better. We are
heartily glad of it, and feel that
the student body as a whole shares
our delight and is equally desirous
of seeing this type of student eliminated from the University rolls.
In calling the nonathletic fee a
"nonessential tax" and nonathletic
activities "the peculiar desire" of
these men, we believe that the
writer displays a misguided opinion. The fee is necessary if these
activities are to be placed on a
par with similar activities in other
educational institutions. It is also
necessary in order that the burden of their support fall equally
upon all who are able to bear it.
If the desire to have our University rank with other leading colleges in undergraduate life is peculiar, the writer is perfectly justified.
The writer also complains
against the payment of the NEWSLETTER and other "noncontracted"
debts from the balance of the students' caution money. We do not
believe that any "noncontracted"
debts are collected in such a manner. If the writer were acquainted with the law, he would know

that anyone who receives any publication and does not notify the
Postoffice authorities that he desires its discontinuance, is legally
bound to pay for it. The NEWSLETTER and other publications are
placed in the student's box in the
expectation that he .will pay for
it as soon as possible, and if he
does not wish it, the time to say
so is at the beginning of the year,
and not at the end, when he has
received the use of it throughout
that time. Class dues are also
justly contracted debts, and the
way to avoid their payment is by
excuse from the treasurer, and not
by ducking at the last minute. Of
course, we realize that some students do not realize that the class,
much less class dues, exist, and
therefore such knowledge comes
as a severe shock. If any other
payments are collected from the
caution money, we feel perfectly
sure that they are justly contiacted, and therefore are indisputable.
We regret the writer's attitude in
this matter, and feel sure that it
does not represent fairly the average poor student. In fact, we
heard some of these men express
the opinion that after they have
succeeded in getting through the
year and met their expenses, they
are only too glad to do their bit to
support the activities by payment
of their NEWS-LETTER and other
bills from their caution money.
We have the greatest sympathy
for the "poor searcher for wisdom," and have no desire to see
this element eliminated from the
student body. We have proved
that the nonathletic fee is not
aimed at this class of students
which Fedders so eloquently describes. We have, however, not
the slightest feeling of charity for
those parasites upon our Alma
Mater who take all from her without giving her the slightest thing
in return, and if the nonathletic
fee will in any way eliminate or
embarrass such students, we are
heartily thankful.

THE WRITER OF THIS LETTER IS
EVIDENTLY NOT IN PERFECT ACCORD WITH THE DEAN.
To the Editor of the News-Letter:

Sir—Your editorial in. the issue
of March 22 professes a mournful
surprise at the rapid and unwept
decease of the "weakly" assembly.
May I be so boorish as to rise
and ask, What has been the specific purpose of these meetings?
Has it been instruction or entertainment? Doubtless my sense of
values is woefully depraved, but I

confess- I have been unable to extract any edification, advantage or
pleasure from most of these gatherings. Nor is this condition to
be marveled at, when the program
is constituted somewhat as follow*: First, the dean mounts the
platform and "obliges" with a linguistic ramble wherein he takes to
task and direly threatens certain
wrongdoers (who, by the way, are
never present to benefit by these
half per cent. philippics); then
some brief routine announcement

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 12, 1921

SOPHS

Seniors

WIN INTERCLASS
TRACK MEET.

second; Reed, Senior, third; Calkins,
Senior, fourth; Martin, Freshman,
fifth. Distance, 34 ft. 91,i in.

Place Second — Aaronson
Stars For Winners.

In the second annual interclass
track meet, held last Friday afternoon at Homewood, the class of
1923 was again victorious, capturing 97 points, more than three
times as many as their nearest
opponents. The Seniors finished
second, with 32 points, while the
Freshmen and Juniors brought up
the rear with 24 and 12 points,
respectively.
In the individual scoring Aaronson lead the field with three firsts
and a second. It was especially
gratifying to see the excellent
showing made by men who had
not been out for track before.
This was, of course, partly due to
the fact that handicaps were given
in the meet this year, but, nevertheless, much new material was
uncovered. Clark, a Sophomore,
showed good form in the dashes,
winning both the 100 and 220
yard events. In the quarter-mile
Edwards ran a beautiful race.
Starting from scratch he overtook
a large field and won by a wide
margin.

goal of the afternoon. He received
the ball in midfield, and after
dodging in and out through the
whole defense shota goal. Bauernschmidt again tied the score with
a shot from the crease just before
the whistle blew time.
Three extra periods failed to
produce a goal by either team, so
the two captains decided to call it
a day. It was, without a doubt,
the best ending for such a game.
A green, well-trained team had
played against an experienced
team, whose players were not in
training, and neither side had the
advantage. For the Alumni,
Mealey, Knipp and Baxley shone
on the attack, while their defense
was always airtight. Griffiss,
Bauernschmidt and Huey played
well on the attack for the Varsity,
while Bachman, Wood and -Zoller
starred on the defense. Benedict
in his first game at goal stopped
many difficult shots, and Murphy
played well at center.
